name: C++ Map
description: C++ <map> are associative containers that store elements formed by a combination of a key value and a mapped value, following a specific order

Iterators.val: Returns an iterator referring to the first element in the map container
Returns an iterator referring to the past-the-end element in the map container
Returns a reverse iterator pointing to the last element in the container
Returns a reverse iterator pointing to the theoretical element right before the first element in the map container
Returns a const_iterator pointing to the first element in the container (C++11 only)
Returns a const_iterator pointing to the past-the-end element in the container (C++11 only)
Returns a const_reverse_iterator pointing to the last element in the container (C++11 only)
Returns a const_reverse_iterator pointing to the theoretical element preceding the first element in the container (C++11 only)

Capacity.val: Returns the number of elements in the map container
Returns the maximum number of elements that the map container can hold
Returns whether the map container is empty

Element Access.val: Returns a reference to the value that is mapped to a key equivalent to key, performing an insertion if such key does not already exist
Returns a reference to the mapped value of the element identified with key k (C++11 only)

Modifiers.val: Inserts element(s) into the container, if the container doesn't already contain an element with an equivalent key
Removes from the map container either a single element or a range of elements
Exchanges the content of the container by the content of x, which is another map of the same type
Removes all elements from the map container (which are destroyed), leaving the container with a size of 0
Inserts a new element in the map if its key is unique. This new element is constructed in place using args as the arguments for the construction of a value_type  (C++11 only)

Inserts a new element in the map if its key is unique, with a hint on the insertion position. This new element is constructed in place using args as the arguments for the construction of a value_type (C++11 only)

Observers.val: Returns a copy of the comparison object used by the container to compare keys
Returns a comparison object that can be used to compare two elements to get whether the key of the first one goes before the second

Operations.val: Searches the container for an element with a key equivalent to k and returns an iterator to it if found, otherwise it returns an iterator to map::end
Searches the container for elements with a key equivalent to k and returns the number of matches
Returns an iterator pointing to the first element in the container whose key is not considered to go before k
Returns an iterator pointing to the first element in the container whose key is considered to go after k
Returns the bounds of a range that includes all the elements in the container which have a key equivalent to k

Allocator.val: Returns a copy of the allocator object associated with the map
